text.p: The Coca-Cola Co. Tuesday unveiled a new aluminum can that mimics the shape of its famous contoured bottle.

The soft-drink giant said the long-awaited packaging innovation, which it hopes will distinguish its canned products from those of its rivals, will be test-marketed in five U.S. markets starting early next month.
The new can will be introduced for the Coca-Cola Classic brand in four Southwestern markets and in Terre Haute, Ind. -- where the contoured bottle first appeared in 1915.
"The proprietary Coca-Cola contour bottle is one of the world's most powerful equities with consumers," Coca-Cola USA President Jack Stahl said in a statement.

"We view the introduction of the contour can as a learning opportunity to assess operational factors before we consider moving toward commercialization of the package. We want to see how the contour can actually works in the marketplace."

Coca-Cola began testing a steel version of the contoured can in Germany in 1994 but had to develop new can-shaping capabilities before it could transfer the innovation to the aluminum cans used in the United States.
Coke introduced a 20-oz. contoured plastic bottle for Coca-Cola Classic three years ago and followed it up with a dimpled 20-oz. bottle for Sprite.
Company executives said the innovations consequently helped the company expand its share of the U.S. soft-drink market.
The company said the contoured can introductions would be supported by local television, print and outdoor advertising.
Coca-Cola's stock added 62.5 cents to $61.25 in midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
